task.task_description: This is a comparative detector design and performance evaluation task for a muon spectrometer system. The task involves designing and simulating a multi-layer detector system that uses iron absorbers to stop hadrons while allowing muons to penetrate, then measuring the detection efficiency and particle discrimination capabilities. The user needs to explore different geometric configurations (planar vs cylindrical), simulate both muon and pion interactions at multiple energies, and quantitatively compare the performance metrics including muon detection efficiency, pion rejection capability, and energy deposition profiles. This is a physics detector optimization task that combines geometric design exploration with Monte Carlo simulation and comparative performance analysis.
task.goal: Design a muon spectrometer that achieves high muon identification efficiency in the 5-100 GeV energy range while effectively rejecting punch-through pions

constraints.description: Energy range: 5-100 GeV (simulation capped at 50 GeV)
Iron absorber thickness: 10-30 cm per layer

task.context:
Design a muon spectrometer for identifying muons in the 5-100 GeV energy range using iron absorbers to stop hadrons.

The system should achieve high muon identification efficiency while rejecting punch-through pions.

**GEOMETRY EXPLORATION:**
Consider different muon system topologies:
- Planar sandwich (iron + tracking layers stacked - simple baseline)
- Cylindrical barrel (iron shells with tracking - ATLAS-style muon barrel)
- Toroidal geometry (used for forward muons with magnetic field)

The geometry tool supports topology="box" or topology="cylinder_barrel" for sampling calorimeter mode.

PRACTICAL CONSTRAINTS:
- Number of iron/scintillator pairs: typically 3-6 for muon spectrometers
- Iron absorber thickness: 10-30 cm per layer typical
- Iron nuclear interaction length λ_I = 16.8 cm (material property)
- Total depth: 3-6 λ_I typical for pion rejection

**ENERGY SWEEP:** Use particle_energy: [5, 20, 50] to run all energies in parallel on GPU.
(Capped at 50 GeV and 3 points to keep simulation tractable)

Simulate BOTH muons and pions, then MEASURE and COMPARE:
1. Muon detection efficiency vs energy (energy deposit in final scintillator layer)
2. Pion stopping probability - measure where pions deposit their energy
3. Energy deposit profile through the detector for each particle type
4. Determine the muon/pion separation power from your measurements

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Use mu- particles for muon simulation
- Use pi- particles at the same energies for comparison
- Test at most 3 configurations exploring topology and/or absorber thickness
- Consider: Does cylindrical geometry provide better angular coverage?

steps.name: design_detector_configurations
steps.description: Calculate optimal detector parameters for 3 muon spectrometer configurations: planar baseline, cylindrical barrel, and thick absorber variant

steps.name: generate_planar_geometry
steps.description: Generate GDML geometry for planar muon spectrometer with 4 iron/scintillator layers, 20cm iron thickness per layer

steps.name: generate_cylindrical_geometry
steps.description: Generate GDML geometry for cylindrical barrel muon spectrometer with 4 iron/scintillator layers, 20cm iron thickness

steps.name: generate_thick_absorber_geometry
steps.description: Generate GDML geometry for planar muon spectrometer with thicker iron absorbers (30cm) for enhanced pion rejection

steps.name: simulate_muons_planar
steps.description: Simulate muon interactions in planar detector at 5, 20, and 50 GeV energies

steps.name: simulate_pions_planar
steps.description: Simulate pion interactions in planar detector at 5, 20, and 50 GeV energies

steps.name: simulate_muons_cylindrical
steps.description: Simulate muon interactions in cylindrical detector at 5, 20, and 50 GeV energies

steps.name: simulate_pions_cylindrical
steps.description: Simulate pion interactions in cylindrical detector at 5, 20, and 50 GeV energies

steps.name: simulate_muons_thick_absorber
steps.description: Simulate muon interactions in thick absorber detector at 5, 20, and 50 GeV energies

steps.name: simulate_pions_thick_absorber
steps.description: Simulate pion interactions in thick absorber detector at 5, 20, and 50 GeV energies

steps.name: analyze_planar_performance
steps.description: Analyze muon detection efficiency, pion rejection, and energy deposition profiles for planar detector

steps.name: plot_planar_results
steps.description: Generate publication-quality plots of energy deposition profiles and efficiency curves for planar detector

steps.name: analyze_cylindrical_performance
steps.description: Analyze muon detection efficiency, pion rejection, and energy deposition profiles for cylindrical detector

steps.name: plot_cylindrical_results
steps.description: Generate publication-quality plots of energy deposition profiles and efficiency curves for cylindrical detector

steps.name: analyze_thick_absorber_performance
steps.description: Analyze muon detection efficiency, pion rejection, and energy deposition profiles for thick absorber detector

steps.name: plot_thick_absorber_results
steps.description: Generate publication-quality plots of energy deposition profiles and efficiency curves for thick absorber detector

steps.name: compare_detector_configurations
steps.description: Quantitatively compare muon detection efficiency, pion rejection factors, and overall performance across all three detector configurations

steps.name: plot_configuration_comparison
steps.description: Generate side-by-side comparison plots showing muon efficiency, pion rejection, and energy deposition for all detector configurations

steps.name: optimize_detector_design
steps.description: Identify optimal detector configuration based on muon efficiency and pion rejection performance across energy range

steps.name: generate_final_report
steps.description: Synthesize all analysis results into comprehensive muon spectrometer design report with performance validation

plan.reasoning: This workflow systematically explores muon spectrometer design by comparing three detector configurations (planar, cylindrical, thick absorber) across the required energy range. Each configuration is simulated with both muons and pions to measure detection efficiency and rejection capability. The approach follows evidence-based analysis with dedicated visualization steps for each configuration and comprehensive comparison. The workflow addresses the core physics challenge of optimizing muon/pion separation while maintaining high muon detection efficiency across 5-50 GeV energy range.

The task involves designing and simulating a multi-layer detector system that uses iron absorbers to stop hadrons while allowing muons to penetrate, then measuring the detection efficiency and particle discrimination capabilities. The user needs to explore different geometric configurations (planar vs cylindrical), simulate both muon and pion interactions at multiple energies, and quantitatively compare the performance metrics including muon detection efficiency, pion rejection capability, and energy deposition profiles. This is a physics detector optimization task that combines geometric design exploration with Monte Carlo simulation and comparative performance analysis.

Status: SUCCESS
Progress: 100.0%
Completed: 20/20 steps
Reasoning: The task is complete. All 20 planned steps were successfully executed, producing the required deliverables: (1) Three detector configurations were designed (planar, cylindrical, thick absorber) with proper geometric specifications, (2) GDML geometry files and simulation macros were generated for all configurations, (3) Monte Carlo simulations were performed for both muons and pions across the energy range (5-50 GeV) for all three geometries, (4) Comprehensive performance analysis was conducted measuring muon detection efficiency, pion rejection capability, and energy deposition profiles, (5) Comparative analysis identified the thick absorber configuration as optimal with 12.75x pion rejection while maintaining 100% muon efficiency, (6) A complete final report was generated documenting the design process, performance validation, and recommendations.
